Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Gene Expression and Physiologic Extremes in Primate Hibernation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hibernation is a seasonal response that some species use to evade energetic demands posed by their environment. Hibernation is characterized by physiologic extremes that would be fatal to non-hibernating species, yet hibernators experience these extremes on an annual basis without harmful effects. Among primates, hibernation is only observed in the dwarf lemurs of Madagascar. Previous work suggests that hibernation is activated not by a set of genes unique to hibernators, but by selective expression of genes that are present in all mammals. This view raises multiple questions, including: Are the physiological processes associated with hibernation shared among all mammalian hibernators (e.g., ground squirrels, bats, bears), or does primate hibernation represent a specialized form of this behavior? Do all mammals, including humans, have the genetic capacity for hibernation? If so, how can we use this information for critical biomedical applications, such as emergency medicine or space travel? Broader impacts also include development of new research collaborations and significant science education and public outreach efforts.

Transcriptome sequencing will be used to identify and quantify genes that are differentially expressed in white adipose tissue from differing physiological states associated with hibernation in 3 dwarf lemur species: one species of captive dwarf lemur (C. medius), and two species of free-ranging dwarf lemurs in Madagascar (C. crossleyi and C. sibreei). This is the first investigation of the genetic control of hibernation in a primate and therefore, this study has implications for understanding hibernation physiology at the most fundamental level. Revealing insights into how primate hibernators successfully display physiologic extremes without morbidity or mortality will have potential applications for biomedical research, and is relevant to the fields of comparative physiology, primate behavior, and evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dwarf lemurs, found only on the island of Madagascar, are among the few primates known to undergo seasonal periods of reduced metabolism and body temperature known as hibernation. Hibernation allows these animals to avoid the harsh and unpredictable environments of Madagascar’s winters. The genetic mechanisms that drive the physiological changes accompanying hibernation have, to date, never been studied in primate hibernators. By including this distantly-related group to the current collection of studies on model mammalian hibernators (e.g. ground squirrels, bats, black bears), this project sought to gain a richer understanding of how the hibernation response is regulated in extant mammal groups, and also yield a better understanding of how hibernation as we see it today may have evolved from early hibernation-like responses in ancestral mammals.

By characterizing gene expression profiles from lemurs in both captive and natural settings, we identified the unique patterns of differential gene expression that are correlated with extreme changes in physiology in two species of dwarf lemurs: Cheirogaleus medius under captive conditions at the Duke Lemur Center and C. crossleyi studied under field conditions in Madagascar. We found that genes that are differentially expressed are present in the genomes of all modern mammals, suggesting that the capacity to use hibernation may still exist in humans and other non-hibernating mammals. Further, a comparative analysis using dwarf lemurs and model mammalian hibernators identified shared genes that regulate hibernation. These genes appear to be critical for maintaining the health of these animals when they undergo prolonged periods of metabolic depression during hibernation.

A portion of this project was conducted at the Duke Lemur Center, in Durham, NC. The Duke Lemur Center advocates for science, outreach, and conservation through cutting-edge, non-invasive research on the behavior and physiology of lemurs. By engaging scientists, students and the public in exciting research discoveries, the Duke Lemur Center promotes a deeper appreciation of the wonders of our natural world and serves as a champion for the scientific method.

Further, results of this research have been shared broadly, not only to the scientific community through publications in scientific journals, but also through outlets accessible to the public. Results from this project have been shared at a talk given at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, as well as a research presentation at the 50th anniversary celebration of the Duke Lemur Center in September 2016. Finally, this work has been shared widely via a BBC radio documentary entitled, “Human Hibernation: The Big Sleep.”
